newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turk shares may rise more, but need fresh impetus.
newsitem.headline: Turk shares may rise more, but need fresh impetus.

text.p: After weeks of rally, fuelled by declining rates, growing hopes for faster sell-offs and lira liquidity, analysts say Turkish stocks have still room for a further rise, but there should be new progress on the economy.
"Most of the expectations have been discounted. From now on, people will look at the actual realisation of these expectations," Erhan Topac, general manager of Gedik Securities, told Reuters.
The Istanbul stock exchange index has risen 59.1 percent since the end of 1996.
"The stock exchange is now in a digestion period," said Ertan Gungor, deputy general manager of private Tekstil Bank.
Gungor said the index had risen very sharply in nominal terms, but it was not very high in real terms.
"The index has yet to reach its $2 level. That means it has not hit its highest point and has some way to go," he added.
In dollar values, the index stood at $1.3 on Friday, up 45 percent since end-1996.
Analysts say any step towards long-awaited key structural measures would push up Turkish share prices further.
Turkey is struggling with high inflation, running at around 80 percent, and huge public deficit, expected to rise above 10 percent of the country's gross national product in 1996.

Businessmen and international financial institutions have long been urging Turkey to speed up privatisation, reform its loss-making social security system and widen its tax base under a medium-term stability programme.

Analysts say Turkey should implement an IMF-backed programme to attract more foreign funds and borrow at lower costs in international markets. Turkish officials said talks with the IMF were expected to resume in March.
